page.title: 04ECOLOGY AND CONSERVATION
page.content: AREA SOUTH OF WESTWOODSIDE ECOLOGY CONSERVARION LAND WILD LIFE APART FROM THE PREDOMINENT FARMLAND, THERE IS AN AREA OF YOUNG WOODLAND, NAMELY LANGHOLME WOOD, WHICH HAS BEEN DEVELOPED OVER THE LAST THIRTY YEARS. IT IS OWNED BY THE LINCOLNSHIRE AND SOUTH HUMBERSIDE TRUST FOR NATURE CONSERVATION, AND WAS DONATED BY TWO LOCAL DOCTORS. AN ACRE OF THIS WOODLAND LHAS BEEN RECENTLY CLEARED OF SYCAMORE AND REPLACED WITH THE NATIVE OAK AND ASH. HEATHERS LHAVE BEEN PLANTED IN THE HEATHLAND CLEARRINGS. THERE ARE ONE OR TWO SSMALLER AREAS OF SCRUB AND BIRCH. A SMALL DECIDUOUS PLANTATION BY THINHOLM FARM HAS BEEN ESTALISHED WITH OAK, BEECH AND SYCAMORE. A VARIETY OF WILD LIFE SHARE THE ENVIRONMENT FOX, STOAT, WEASLE, OTTER. 101 DIFFERENT WILD FLOWERS. A REDUCTION IN INSECT LIFE NOTED.
